content: The Bipartisan Panel to Design Long-Range Social Security Reform Act of 1998 establishes a panel to design recommendations for long-term reforms to restore the solvency of the social security system and ensure retirement income security in the United States. The Bipartisan Panel to Design Long-Range Social Security Reform Act of 1998 establishes an eight-member panel appointed by various government officials to represent recognized standing and distinction for designing long-term social security reforms. The Bipartisan Panel to Design Long-Range Social Security Reform Act of 1998 establishes an eight-member panel appointed by government officials to represent various interests, with Co-Chairs designated to supervise the Panel's duties for its lifetime, ensuring vacancies do not hinder its functions. The Bipartisan Panel to Design Long-Range Social Security Reform Act of 1998 establishes an eight-member panel appointed by government officials to represent various interests. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Bipartisan Panel to Design Long-Range Social Security Reform Act of 1998 establishes an eight-member panel appointed by government officials to represent various interests. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. PROCEDURES. The Panel established by the Bipartisan Panel to Design Long-Range Social Security Reform Act of 1998 will meet as called by its Co-Chairs or majority of members. A quorum consists of 4 members, with the option for a lesser number to conduct hearings. The Panel may hold hearings and other activities as necessary, with fact-finding meetings open to the public and policy development meetings in executive session. The Panel can request information from the Commissioner of Social Security and other government agencies. The Federal Government must provide necessary information to the Panel for it to carry out its duties. The administration of the Panel is outlined in Section 6. The Panel members do not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits, except for travel expenses and per diem. The staff director is appointed and compensated at a specified rate. Additional staff may also be appointed by the Panel. The Panel may appoint additional personnel as needed, including experts and consultants. Staff members are appointed without following civil service laws and may receive compensation without adhering to certain pay regulations. The Panel also has the authority to contract with government and private agencies for services. The Panel on a reimbursable basis may use government and private agencies for services, including detailing federal employees and utilizing the United States mails. The Panel may use government and private agencies for services, including administrative support from the Architect of the Capitol and printing services as a committee of Congress. The Panel must submit a report by February 1, 1999, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations approved by at least 6 members. The Panel will terminate on March 31, 1999, with authorized appropriations not exceeding $2,000,000 from the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund.
